posts.text: If halligan can't officially represent the DOJ, and she is in the chain of custody for property that is supposed to be under the DOJ's control, that's probably bad unless she is some sort of forensic expert brought in to do a special analysis, which is clearly not the case.

reply_context.text: My understanding is that the delay in the government identifying their counsel at least has the optics of them not knowing who had possession of the property, and now they're trying to bypass filing officially on the docket because DOJ no longer has grounds to claim halligan is a US Attorney.

not a lawyer, but I'm reasonably confident nothing about this normal.

Linked the dec 6th order for context. I think what makes this situation slightly more complicated is that the government's representation is tied to the chain of custody of the property.

posts.text: Honestly, it's going to be bad for businesses too, not just academia. Multinational companies based in the US (e.g. any FAANG) won't be able to hold all-hands conferences stateside.

reply_context.text: The US social media vetting for visas will be devastating for scientific and journalistic conferences, fellowships etc. No global organisation can seriously consider holding an international conference in the US while this policy exists.
